title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.24 | 18-02-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: My dear Krishna, Your Lordship has protected us from a poison cake, from a great fire, from cannibals, from the vicious assembly, from sufferings during our exile in the world.
segments.summary: Queen Kunti's prayer listing the dangers Krishna saved her and her sons from is introduced.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 24th verse of the 8th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. विशान महागने पुरुषाद दर्शनात अससभाया वनवास कृच्रतः मृधे मृधे नेक महारथास्त्रतो द्रोवन्यस्त्रतः चास्म हरे भी रक्षिताह. The meaning of this verse is a prayer by Queen Kunti to Lord Krishna: "My dear Krishna, Your Lordship has protected us from a poison cake, from a great fire, from cannibals, from the vicious assembly, from sufferings during our exile in the world. You have saved us from the forest and from the battle where great generals fought, and now you have saved us from the weapon of Ashwatthama."

segments.key_quote: This is the reciprocation of the Lord with his devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker compares Devaki's and Kunti's situations, highlighting the constant dangers Kunti faced and Krishna's protection, emphasizing the Lord's reciprocation with devotees.
segments.transcript: So, here is a list of different dangerous encounters that Kunti Devi, along with her sons, had to face. Srila Prabhupada explains this very nicely in the purport. The list of dangerous encounters is submitted here in Devaki, because in the previous verse there is a reference to Devaki, who was protected as much as Kunti was also protected. But Prabhupada is comparing Devaki's situation with Kunti's situation. Devaki was once put into difficulty by her envious brother. Otherwise, she was well. So, Kunti and her sons were put into one difficulty after another for years and years together. See the difference? Devaki, after she was imprisoned and you see Krishna was born and Krishna was transferred to Vrindavan. And then, Devaki's problems were over. But Kunti Devi and her sons were put into so many different dangerous situations, so many difficulties. They were put into trouble by Duryodhana and his party due to the kingdom. And each and every time, the sons of Kunti were saved by Lord Krishna.

segments.key_quote: My devotee will never be vanquished.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes Krishna's promise in the Bhagavad Gita that His devotees will never be vanquished, illustrating this with the Pandavas' survival despite numerous attempts on their lives.
segments.transcript: This is the reciprocation of the Lord with his devotees. Therefore, Krishna says in the Bhagavad Gita, Name Bhakta Pranasyati Kaunteya Pratijaanihi Name Bhakta Pranasyati: "My devotee will never be vanquished." And that's a fact. Though they tried to kill the Pandavas, the Kauravas could never succeed in doing so.

segments.key_quote: And Bhima in this way was actually saved from being killed by Krishna's arrangement. It was Krishna's arrangement.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the reaction of Kunti and Duryodhana to Bhima's reappearance, emphasizing that Bhima's survival was due to Krishna's arrangement.
segments.transcript: Bhima was given special medication to increase his strength to that of 10,000 elephants, so Bhima became very very very strong and then the Nagas again brought him back to that river and left him on the bank of that river and then Bhima was missing from the palace for some days and Kunti was very worried and so. segments.key_quote: So Yudhishthira through Vidura's help, he dug a tunnel as soon as they went into the palace.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of the house of shellac, Vidura's warning, and the Pandavas' escape through a tunnel, highlighting their intelligence and Krishna's protection.
segments.transcript: And Bhima in this way was actually saved from being killed by Krishna's arrangement. It was Krishna's arrangement. Then once they were put into a house made of shellac. Now each of these dangers that are mentioned, it is elaborately explained in the Mahabharata. So I will not be able to explain each and every particular danger like that. But in brief I may state that another attempt was made to burn the Pandavas alive by sending them to a new palace that was called Kunti. It was constructed but it was made of combustible material, shellac. And Duryodhana's plan was to set fire when they were all settled inside nicely one particular night. So Vidura came to know about it and Vidura informed Yudhishthira that you are being sent to a palace which is going to set fire. Be careful. So Yudhishthira through Vidura's help, he dug a tunnel as soon as they went into the palace. He dug a tunnel. And before escaping through the tunnel, underground tunnel, Yudhishthira himself set fire to that palace. And then after that the Pandavas with Kunti escaped.

segments.key_quote: But Draupadi was supplied with unlimited length of sari.
segments.summary: The speaker recounts the attempted disrobing of Draupadi and Krishna's miraculous intervention, as well as Bhima's fight with the demon Hidimba.
segments.transcript: And then that's the way they were saved from that fire. So then Draupadi was dragged out and attempted to be stripped naked once in a gambling match. Somehow that gambling match that happened. And Draupadi was saved by Krishna who supplied her unlimited length of sari. They tried to disrobe her by pulling her sari. But Draupadi was supplied with unlimited length of sari. So they could not strip her naked at all. Krishna saved her. She cried out Krishna. Because the Pandavas were unable to intervene because they had lost themselves in the gambling match. So they were unable to save her. And the other elders in the assembly did not interfere with this Duryodhana and Dushasana's misdeed, because Draupadi also was kind of lost in the gambling match and she would become a kind of a servant to the Kauravas. Something like that. Then when they were exiled in the forest, Bhima had to fight with the man-eater demon Hidimba, Rakshasa. So one Rakshasa, man-eater. But Bhima killed this Rakshasa. Again, Krishna's mercy that Bhima was empowered to kill this man-eater who was a very dangerous Rakshasa, who had killed many humans and devoured them and eaten their flesh.

segments.key_quote: But Krishna, he protected Arjuna and the Pandavas.
segments.summary: The speaker briefly mentions the Kurukshetra battle and Ashwathama's Brahmastra, emphasizing Krishna's constant protection of the Pandavas.
segments.transcript: Such a dangerous man-eater was killed by Bhima because he was empowered by the Lord. Then after all this tribulation there was a great battle of Kurukshetra. Arjuna had to meet such great generals as Drona, Bhishma, Karna. All very very powerful fighters. But Krishna, he protected Arjuna and the Pandavas. And no harm was done by the Kauravas. Even though the Kauravas were very powerful, they could not do any harm to the Pandavas. And at the end when Parikshit was in the womb of Uttara, then Ashwathama released the Brahmastra to kill the child. But Krishna saved. Krishna personally entered the womb of Uttara and saved the child. So in this way the Pandavas were protected by Krishna at all times, whenever there was danger to their life, whenever there was any difficulty.
